answers.a: Yes—magnesium stearate (E572) is considered safe at permitted levels by major regulators (e.g., FDA GRAS; EFSA/JECFA no safety concern at typical uses).

answers.q: is magnesium stearate bad for your liver
answers.a: There’s no evidence it harms the liver at normal food or supplement levels; stearate is metabolized like other dietary fats and the magnesium contribution is minimal.

answers.q: what is magnesium stearate used for
answers.a: It’s used as a lubricant/flow agent in tablets and capsules and as an anti-caking or release agent in foods to help powders flow and prevent sticking.

answers.q: is magnesium stearate bad for you
answers.a: No—at normal use levels it isn’t associated with harm; very high intakes may cause mild digestive upset in some people.
It’s the same compound made from plant-derived stearic acid (e.g., palm or other vegetable oils) rather than animal fat, labeled for vegetarian or dietary preference reasons.
